note: Specialized runner - see extra_data for details

extra.raw_output:
Part 1: Project Background  
The provided `RandomNumberGenerator` contract is a utility meant to supply pseudorandom numbers (in the range [1, max]) for games or other consuming contracts. It initializes a private `salt` based on the block’s timestamp at deployment, then combines that with the current block number and a blockhash to produce a “random” output. There is no external interface to call `random` (it is `private`), so this contract is expected to be inherited or referenced by other contracts that expose a public/random API. The goal is to abstract away randomness generation, but as implemented it is both predictable and carries an arithmetic defect.

Part 2: Function Breakdown and Call Relationships  
Source file: RandomNumberGenerator.sol

Lines 12–13  
• uint256 private salt = block.timestamp;  
  – Purpose: Establish an initial entropy seed based on the deployment timestamp.  
  – No dependencies or calls.

Lines 14–24  
Function random(uint max) view private returns (uint256 result)  
• Signature: random(uint max)  
• Scope: `private`, so only this contract’s own code (or derived contracts) can invoke it.  
• Purpose: Compute a pseudorandom number between 1 and max.  
  – Line 16: compute x = salt * 100 / max  
  – Line 18: compute y = salt * block.number / (salt % 5)  
  – Line 20: compute seed = block.number / 3 + (salt % 300) + y  
  – Line 22: fetch blockhash(seed)  
  – Line 24: return ((h / x) % max) + 1  
• Call relationships:  
  – No internal calls to other functions in this contract.  
  – Only uses global variables and EVM built-ins (`block.number`, `blockhash`, `block.timestamp` via `salt`).  

Part 3: Vulnerability Assessment (DASP Top 10)  
reentrancy: 0  
access_control: 0  
arithmetic: 1  
unchecked_low_level_calls: 0  
denial_of_service: 0  
bad_randomness: 1  
front_running: 0  
time_manipulation: 0  
short_addresses: 0  
other: 0  

Identified issues:  
1) arithmetic (division by zero)  
   – In `random()`, y = salt * block.number / (salt % 5). If `salt % 5 == 0` (possible when the deployment timestamp is an exact multiple of 5), this division reverts, causing any call to `random` to fail.  
2) bad_randomness (predictable RNG)  
   – All entropy sources (`salt`, `block.number`, `blockhash`, `block.timestamp`) are public or miner-controlled, making outputs predictable and manipulable by miners or observers.  

Part 4: Findings as JSON  
[
  {
    "category": "arithmetic",
    "title": "Division by zero if salt % 5 equals zero",
    "evidence": {
      "file": "RandomNumberGenerator.sol",
      "lines": [18],
      "function": "random"
    },
    "explanation": "The expression `salt % 5` may evaluate to zero (if the timestamp at deployment was divisible by 5), causing a division by zero in the computation of `y` and reverting the function.",
    "influence_scope": {
      "functions": ["random"],
      "lines": [18]
    }
  },
  {
    "category": "bad_randomness",
    "title": "Predictable pseudorandom number generator",
    "evidence": {
      "file": "RandomNumberGenerator.sol",
      "lines": [12, 16, 18, 20, 22, 24],
      "function": "random"
    },
    "explanation": "The RNG relies solely on public block variables (`block.number`, `blockhash(seed)`, `block.timestamp`) and a static `salt`, all of which are visible or manipulable by miners. This makes the output trivially predictable and subject to miner influence.",
    "influence_scope": {
      "functions": ["random"],
      "lines": [12, 16, 18, 20, 22, 24]
    }
  }
]
